boat.name: Flirt
boat.full_description:
A rare 21’ open day boat with steel centre plate, No. 11 of 11 GRP facsimiles of an original 19th century Yealm Crabber working boat. Built by Newton Ferrers based Hockaday Brother in the late 1980’s. 
This example allegedly built by the boat builders for themselves and of a high peak gaff configuration with short bowsprit. A couple of other examples found on line but differ in rig.
The hull moulds were apparently also used to make the colourful whaler rowing boats raced at Yealm & Dartmouth regattas.
Extensively overhauled and refitted following purchase Autumn 2019 benefiting from additional attention during the 2020 Covid lockdown. 
Now based on the River Dart and discovered to be a fast hull with powerful rig. These features tie in with the online conjecture that the original design was designed for quick access to offshore crabbing grounds some distance from the mouth of the Yealm.
boat.short_description:
No. 11 of a small series of fibreglass Yealm Crabbers built in the late ‘80’s by the Hockadays at Newton Ferrers from a mould taken from an original Crabber built by their forebears. All seem to have been fitted out with a variety of rigs although information about the type is scant.

Hull moulds also used for the Whaler rowing boats used annually at Dartmouth and Yealm Regattas.

Thorough overhaul and refit winter 2019 into Covid 2020 lockdown.

A fast hull design with powerful rig.
reference: "Crabbers of the Yealm" Classic Boat magazine edition 9, 1988
